column2:
Level(s) is the European Commission’s first-ever
framework to improve the sustainability of buildings.
Using existing standards, it offers a new approach
to assess and reporting on the sustainability of
buildings throughout their full lifecycle.
column3: 1) To provide a clear set of priorities for a building’s performance and a standardised basis for setting requirements for new and renovated buildings.
column7:
Public authorities, policy-makers and procurers at national, regional and local level, architects, designers,
engineers, and quantity
surveyors, clients and investors, including property owners, and developers, construction companies and contractors, manufacturers, asset managers, facilities managers, and occupants.

column2: LCA addressess the environmental aspects and potential environmental impacts throughout a product's life cycle from raw material acqusition to final disposal.

column8: Assesses the environmental impacts of the products from a life cycle perspective, comparing different scenarios as: no-action scenario, retrofitting scenario, innovative scenario , and informing stakeholders on best alternatives.
column11:
There are 4 main phases: 
- Goal and scope
- Inventory analysis
- Impact assessment
- Interpretation
column12:
The impacts are classified into 12 categories: 
Climate change, stratospheric ozone depletion, tropospheric ozone (smog) creation, eutrophication, acidification, toxicological stress on human health and ecosystems, the depletion of resources, among others.

column2:
The Itaca Protocol is a tool for assessing the level of energy and environmental sustainability of buildings.

The Protocol makes it possible to verify the performance of a building in reference to:
-  building consumption
- energy efficiency
-  impact on the environment
- impact on human health.                                                          The ITACA Protocol is derived from the SBTool international evaluation model, developed as part of the Green Building Challenge research process, and contextualized to the Italian territory in relation to the reference legislation and its environmental characteristics.
column3:
The Itaca Protocol has different uses and purposes in relation to its different use:

1) is a design support tool for professionals.
2) is a control and guidance tool for the public administration.
3) supports  the choice of  consumer.
4) enhances an investment for financial operators.
column7: All building stakeholders accross all building lifecycle from design and construction stages to end users, including governance level.
column8: Addresses building sustainability, energy efficiency,human health.
column11: Building scale (residential and non residential buildings).
column12:
Multi-criteria analysis system for assessing environmental sustainability, structured according to three hierarchical levels:

1) Areas, which represent macro-themes that are considered significant for the purposes of assessing the environmental sustainability of a building, such as:
Area A. Site quality
Area B. Consumption of resources
Area C. Environmental loads
Area D. Indoor environmental quality
Area E. Quality of service

2) Categories, each of which deals with a particular aspect of the area topic to which it belongs.

3) Criteria, each of which explores a particular aspect of the category to which they belong. Finally, the criteria represent the evaluation items of the method and are used to characterize the building's performance at the beginning of the evaluation process.
column13: The Protocol  is mandatory for interventions with public funding exceeding 50%

column3:
The objective of this protocol, which will act in synergy with other protocols relating to building sustainability  and facilitate appropriate responses to urban regeneration, is:
1) To provide a cross-scale assessment that will measure the sustainability level of interventions in urban environments ranging in size from the block to the city. Thus, it will be useful for public planning bodies and all those stakeholders in developing or transforming urban areas in order to implement its use also in support of financing programs at national level for urban regeneration.

The protocol, although reflecting the analogous building-scale protocol, is structured on a set of significantly more open and inclusive principles that have led to evaluation criteria for environmental, economic and sustainability of the interventions. The macro themes on which the evaluation is based concern governance, including the participatory process, city planning aspects, urban landscape quality, architectural aspects, public spaces, urban metabolism, biodiversity, adaptation, mobility and accessibility, society, culture and economy.
column7: All buildings and urban spaces/neiborhood  stakeholders accross all building lifecycle from design and construction stages to end users, with a stron focus on  governance and public authorities.
column8: Urban regeneration, mobility, public spaces, social inclusion, urban metabolism, access and flexilbility of spaces, human health.
